general: This law allows police officers to arrest someone without a warrant if they are wanted for a serious crime in another country. This means that if someone has committed a crime like murder or terrorism in another country, our police can arrest them here even if they haven't been formally charged yet. The idea is to make it easier to bring criminals to justice by streamlining the process of extraditing them back to their home country.

series.short: The Extradition (Provisional Arrest) Act 2020: New Powers for Law Enforcement Authorities
series.text:
* Simplified point 1: The Extradition (Provisional Arrest) Act 2020 gives law enforcement authorities the power toarrest individuals without a warrant if they are suspected of committing a "serious offence" in another country.
* Simplified point 2: The Act applies to all parts of the United Kingdom and can be used to extend the powers of extradition to British overseas territories, the Channel Islands, and the Isle of Man.
* Simplified point 3: The Act allows for the Secretary of State to set different dates for different provisions to come into force, and makes provision for transitional or saving arrangements.
* Simplified point 4: The Act may be cited as the Extradition (Provisional Arrest) Act 2020.

summary: The Extradition (Provisional Arrest) Act 2020 is a new law that lets police officers arrest people without a warrant if they are suspected of committing a serious crime in another country. This law applies to all parts of the UK, including British overseas territories like Gibraltar and the Falkland Islands. It also means that the government can change when different parts of the law come into effect, and make sure there are no problems with existing laws. This law is important because it helps the UK work with other countries to catch criminals who have committed serious crimes, like murder or terrorism.
single:
* Creates a power of arrest without a warrant for the purpose of extraditing individuals for serious offenses.
* Contains consequential amendments and a power to make further amendments.
* Any amendment or repeal made by this act has the same extent within the United Kingdom as the provision amended or repealed.
* The powers under sections 177 and 222 of the Extradition Act 2003 may be exercised in relation to any amendment or repeal made by this act.
* Comes into force on the day it is passed, except for certain provisions that may be commenced at a later date.
* Allows the Secretary of State to make transitional or saving provisions in connection with the coming into force of any provision of this act.
* Regulations under this section are to be made by statutory instrument.
